Class CreatureHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • CreatureHandler

  • public class CreatureHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    The "brains" of the game, which controls all of the creature activites.

    Since:
    2016-12-08
    See Also:
    Creature

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      CreatureHandler(int worldRows, int worldCols, java.util.List<Creature> creatures) 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.util.List<Creature> getCreatures()
      Retrieves all of the creatures that exist in the world
      void setStartingPositions()
      Sets the initial positions of the creatures to random locations within the world's grid.
      void updateCreatures()
      Updates all of the living creatures in the game by making they each get a chance to act on their implemented behaviors.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • CreatureHandler

        public CreatureHandler(int worldRows,
                       int worldCols,
                       java.util.List<Creature> creatures)
        Parameters:
        worldRows - How many rows the world grid should have.
        worldCols - How many columns the world grid should have.
        creatures - A list of creatures to start the world with.

    • Method Detail

      • getCreatures

        public java.util.List<Creature> getCreatures()
        Retrieves all of the creatures that exist in the world
        Returns:
        A list of the creatures in the world.

      • setStartingPositions

        public void setStartingPositions()
        Sets the initial positions of the creatures to random locations within the world's grid.

      • updateCreatures

        public void updateCreatures()
        Updates all of the living creatures in the game by making they each get a chance to act on their implemented behaviors.
